[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], United States | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Louisiana blues]], [[swamp blues]] | occupation = [[Guitar]]ist, [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = | label = [[Excello Records|Excello]], [[Stateside Records|Stateside]], [[Flyright Records|Flyright]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Lightnin' Slim''' (March 13, 1913 - July 27, 1974) was an [[African American|African]]-[[United States|American]] [[Louisiana blues]] musician,{{cite book | first= Paul | last= Du Noyer | year= 2003 | title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music | edition= 1st | publisher= Flame Tree Publishing | location= Fulham, London | isbn= 1-904041-96-5 | page= 181}} who recorded for [[Excello Records]] and played in a style similar to its other Louisiana artists. Blues critic [[ED Denson]] has ranked him as one of the five great bluesmen of the 1950s, along with [[Muddy Waters]], [[Little Walter]], [[Howlin' Wolf]] and [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]].{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} ==Career== Lightnin' Slim was born '''Otis V. Hicks''' on a farm outside [[St. Louis, Missouri]].{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lightnin-slim-mn0000220710/biography |title=Lightnin' Slim |author=Cub Coda |publisher=www.allmusic.com |year=2013 |accessdate=12 October 2013}} moving to [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] at the age of thirteen. Taught guitar by his older brother Layfield, Slim was playing in bars in Baton Rouge by the late 1940s.{{cite web |url=http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus-lslim.htm |title=Lightnin' Slim / Otis Hicks |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Thebluestrail.com |accessdate=November 19, 2011}} He debuted on [[J. D. "Jay" Miller]]'s Feature Records label in 1954 with "Bad Luck Blues" (''"If it wasn't for bad luck, I wouldn't have no luck at all"'').{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | pages= 135–6 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} Slim then recorded for [[Excello Records]] for twelve years, starting in the mid-1950s, often collaborating with his brother-in-law, [[Slim Harpo]] and with harmonica player [[Lazy Lester]]. Slim took time off from the blues for a period of time and ended up working in a foundry in [[Pontiac, Michigan]],{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} which resulted in him suffering from constantly having his hands exposed to high temperatures. He was re-discovered by Fred Reif in 1970, in Pontiac, where he was living in a rented room at Slim Harpo's sister's house. Reif soon got him back performing again and a new recording contract with Excello, this time through Bud Howell, the present President of the company. His first gig was a reunion concert at the 1971 University of Chicago Folk Festival with Lazy Lester, whom Reif had brought from Baton Rouge in January 1971. In the 1970s, Slim performed on tours in Europe, both in the United Kingdom and at the [[Montreux Jazz Festival]] in Switzerland where he was often accompanied by [[Moses "Whispering" Smith]] on [[harmonica]]. He last toured the UK in 1973, with the American Blues Legends package.{{cite book | first= John | last= Tobler | year= 1992 | title= NME Rock 'N' Roll Years | edition= 1st | publisher= Reed International Books Ltd | location= London | page= 266 | id= CN 5585}} In July 1974, Slim died of stomach cancer in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], aged 61.{{cite book |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=s9PeKHhZIK4C&pg=PA127&lpg=PA127&dq=lightnin+slim+stomach+cancer+detroit&source=bl&ots=WRJyPUAjSI&sig=2a9i-CVkoKarSRPJY_73bIlH2YQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5rVZUriGL-ax0AW9j4CQCA&sqi=2&ved=0CFcQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=lightnin%20slim%20stomach%20cancer%20detroit&f=false |title=South to Louisiana: The Music of the Cajun Bayous |author=John Broven |publisher=Pelican Publishing Company |year=1983 |accessdate=12 October 2013}} Slim has been cited as a major influence by several contemporary blues artists, including [[Captain Beefheart]], who in a 1987 radio interview with [[Kristine McKenna]], stated that Lightnin' Slim was the only artist he could recommend somebody
